user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 start_time, uint32 interval_time)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *local;
    struct itimerspec                   timeout;
    int32                               return_code;
    int                                 status;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *     timebase;

    local       = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);
    timebase    = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, *token);
    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    /* There is only something to do here if we are generating a simulated tick */
    if (local->assigned_signal != 0)
    {
        /*
        ** Convert from Microseconds to timespec structures
        */
        memset(&timeout, 0, sizeof(timeout));
        OS_UsecToTimespec(start_time, &timeout.it_value);
        OS_UsecToTimespec(interval_time, &timeout.it_interval);

        /*
        ** Program the real timer
        */
        status = timer_settime(local->host_timerid, 0, /* Flags field can be zero */
                               &timeout,               /* struct itimerspec */
                               NULL);                  /* Oldvalue */

        if (status < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error in timer_settime: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            return_code = OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL;
        }
        else if (interval_time > 0)
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_interval.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
        else
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_value.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
    }

    local->reset_flag = (return_code == OS_SUCCESS);
    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t OS_impl_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t       handler_thread;
    pthread_mutex_t handler_mutex;
    timer_t         host_timerid;
    int             assigned_signal;
    sigset_t        sigset;
    sig_atomic_t    reset_flag;
    struct timespec softsleep;
} OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
static void OS_UsecToTimespec(uint32 usecs, struct timespec *time_spec)
{
    if (usecs < 1000000)
    {
        time_spec->tv_nsec = (usecs * 1000);
        time_spec->tv_sec  = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        time_spec->tv_sec  = usecs / 1000000;
        time_spec->tv_nsec = (usecs % 1000000) * 1000;
    }
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL (-32)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no occurrences of compiler language extensions in the provided code. The constructs used are standard C and POSIX library features rather than compiler-specific extensions:
- Use of standard C library functions/types: memset, strerror, errno, NULL, size operators, standard integer typedefs (uint32/uint32_t).  
- Use of POSIX types and APIs: pthread_t, pthread_mutex_t, timer_t, struct itimerspec / struct timespec, timer_settime, sigset_t, sig_atomic_t — these are platform/POSIX APIs, not compiler language extensions.  
- Use of inline (static inline OS_ObjectIndexFromToken) and variadic macros (OS_DEBUG) are standard since C99 and are not compiler-specific extensions by themselves.  
- Macros and typedefs used (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_DEBUG, OS_SUCCESS, etc.) are standard preprocessor and typedef usage.  
- No occurrences of commonly-known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions (GCC’s ({ ... })), nested functions, anonymous structs/unions with nonstandard syntax, or other vendor-specific keywords were found.

Because the rule triggers only for explicit compiler language extensions (as documented by a compiler), and none of those constructs appear in the code, there are no suspicious fragments to report for Rule 1.2.
